body:
I'd like to do something with this. Could you give me a quick run down of the parameters above. This is what I am assuming:

metric: str - the metric name. What values can this be?
resamples: int - the number of resamples. Is this the number of folds you want to look at? What values can this be?
toolkit: str - the toolkit str. This one im not to sure what it is indicating.
classifiers: arr[str] - array of classifiers. What values can this be?

In terms of the return 2D array im assuming you want something like this:

[["Rocket", 0.82], ["BOSS", 0.92], ["HC2", 0.90]]

not a full list, I'll sort that after lunch, but just posting quick summary
metric str: default to accuracy, others include nll, f1, auc
resamples: int - the number of resamples. number of resamples/folds to recover. default to 1 (standard train/test split) max 30 
toolkit: str - either sktime or tsml, default sktime
classifiers: arr[str] - array of classifiers. list to follow
problem_list arr[str] - default to full problem list, (thats listed somewhere 

I was thinking of returning just a 2D array  of problem (rows) x classifier (cols), where values are averaged over resamples. We could configure the option to give more complex output, hash table of classifier and 2D array.

we also need to deal with missing values, since some classifiers have not been evaluated on all problems.

hi chris, I will rearrange the file structure later, but for development you can try loading this file
https://timeseriesclassification.com/results/ResultsByClassifier/TSF_TESTFOLDS.csv
and the other thing is where to put this. Just chuck it in contrib in the first instance, I may ask a student to do a workbook based on it

issue.title: basic classifier result setup

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
#1123 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->
Basic implementation of the result collation for classifiers. So far it is reading the results from the timeseriesclassification website and is placing them in dataframes. Waiting for instructions on how to continue with this.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->
Let me know where you want me to continue @TonyBagnall 

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body: we have some prototype code to do this, but on reflection I don't think we want this in sktime proper, since it will introduce a dependency on an external website (timeseriesclassification.com). Unless anyone objects, I will close this issue

this does not seem like a correct statement - we do have a dependency already on timeserieslassification.com through many of the functions in `sktime.datasets.`, so we wouldn't be introducing it.

Further, users are actually asking for it - see, e.g., https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/discussions/3186 - so it sounds like a useful piece of functionality.

Also, for scientific purposes, to allow our users to easily compare new algorithms against previously reported results, or compare reported results against replication studies.

I would hence disagree to close this issue.

we have a dependency on tsc.com for loading data from the website, but somewhere you said you were working to disconnect sktime from any UEA infrastructure, which includes tsc.,com, so I assumed you were against it. Maybe I misunderstood. I'm more than happy to have it in sktime proper. btw, the discussion you point to was one of my MSc students, who has since finished. We resolved his query offline. I have not seem any other requests for this functionality, have you?

I am in the process of rerunning all experiments with sktime 0.12 to bake them in for 100% reproducibility and comparison to tsml. Once I get them on the website I will port in the code to read and format once it is sktime ready, its a bit hacky atm.
